body.p:
Louisville Ky
December 2d 186
His Excellency Thos E Bramlette
Dear Sir on the other Side of this Sheet you will find the verdict of the Jury in the case of Wm Kelly You will See that the Jury reccommend him for your executive mercy for Pardon.

I was appointed by the court to defend him and did it without pay of course. He had been in the U. S. army for 3 years and more had been discharged, got his pay and was boarding Staying and drinking around one of those low-down Irish doggeries, and boarding houses -- had been on a drunk for 8 or 10 days, and the Irishman had got most of his money -- He got up one morning, and his panteloons, hat and boots were gone. He thought the Landlord or his wife had taken them, So he Says, and in hunting through the house for them he Saw a watch lying on the bureau He says he put it in his pocket and told the man's wife that if She would get his pants, hat, &c he would find the watch -- He got his wa clothes, and then went and and got the watch and gave it up. There was no witness present at the trial but the Irish doggery Keeper and he suppress all the facts in the case except that he missed his wa and found in possession of Kelly.

I think the Governor that Kelly's Statements were true, and that the taking was not felonious. I trust
therefore you will Send me a pardon for him at once.

I do hereby certify that Wm Kelly who was Indicted in the Jefferson Circuit court for Grand Larceny and tried at the present November term of Said court and convicted; and that the verdict of the Jury is at follows viz:

"We of the Jury find the prisoner Wm Kelly guilty as charged in the within indictment and Say he Shall be confined in the Jail and Penetentiary of this Commonwealth one year, and recommend him to the mercy of the Governor for Pardon

December 2d 1865
A Copy.
Att Jas P Chambers clk

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Wm Kelly
Grand Larceny
1 year
Pardoned
4th Dec 1865
